text: explore functionality BLN ecosystem service crop produciton, ’ll use dataset bln_farm_hf. dataset contains soil properties 11 agricultural fields owned research farm Wageningen University Research, properties estimated data National Agricultural Soil Archive NMI, documented ?bln_farm_hf. field, following properties available 10 year period: field properties: ID, landuse (B_LU_BRP) agricultural region (B_AER_CBS), geometry (geom) basic soil properties: soil type (B_SOILTYPE_AGR, B_HELP_WENR), risk soil compaction (B_SC_WENR) groundwater level (B_GWL_CLASS) chemical, physical biological soil properties obtained measurements (variables starting “A_”) measurements done via Visual Soil Assessment Form (optional, variables starting “A_” ending “BCS”). details, see Assessment Form Bodemconditiescore. short snapshot bln_farm_hf given: numerical input variables BLN. categorial input variables BLN. example optional input variables set lowest score (visuals soil assessment). Since soil quality can evaluated given use, crop rotation (sequence crops cultivated time) determines also soil properties soil functions relevant evaluated given desired threshold value. Note bln_farm_hf data.table, modern fast variant data.frame. ’s particularly useful large datasets prints selection dataset calculations done data.table extremely fast. can learn data.tables link; particular can convert data frames data.tables data.table::.data.table().
code: # dimensions of the database   dim(bln_farm_hf) #> [1] 330  78    # format in a long table, and subset the numeric columns only   dt2 <- copy(bln_farm_hf)[id==1 & year==2022][,c('geom','ref_id_2022') := NULL]    # select numeric values and round to two digits   cols <- colnames(dt2)[grepl('^A_|a_|d_|D_|B_CT|B_GWL_G|DEGRE|B_GWL_Z',colnames(dt2))]   dt2[,c(cols) := lapply(.SD,function(x) fifelse(x<1,round(x,2),fifelse(x<10,round(x,1),round(x)))),.SDcols = cols]    # melt the data.table   dt.melt1 <- melt(dt2[,mget(c(cols,'id','year'))],                    id.vars = c('id','year'),                   variable.name = 'parameter', value.name = 'value')    # print the table in nice format   knitr::kable(      list(dt.melt1[1:14,3:4],dt.melt1[15:28,3:4],dt.melt1[29:42,3:4],dt.melt1[43:56,3:4]),      caption = 'numerical input variables for BLN.',      booktabs = TRUE  ) # do the same for the categorial values      # format in a long table, and subset the numeric columns only   dt3 <- copy(bln_farm_hf)[id==1 & year==2022][,c('geom','ref_id_2022') := NULL]      # select categorial variables   cols2 <- colnames(dt3)[!colnames(dt3) %in% cols]      # convert to chracter   dt3 <- dt3[,lapply(.SD,as.character),.SDcols = cols2]      # melt the data.table   dt.melt2 <- melt(dt3[,mget(cols2)],                    id.vars = c('id','year'),                   variable.name = 'parameter', value.name = 'value')    # print the table in nicer format   knitr::kable(      list(dt.melt2[1:9,3:4],dt.melt2[10:18,3:4]),      caption = 'categorial input variables for BLN.',      booktabs = TRUE  )

code: # select the data for de Marke farm   dt <- copy(BLN::bln_farm_hf)   dt <- dt[id==1]      # run the bln_field with default management measures and no visual assessment data   o1 <- bln_field(ID = dt$id,B_LU_BRP = dt$B_LU_BRP,B_SC_WENR = dt$B_SC_WENR,             B_GWL_CLASS = dt$B_GWL_CLASS,B_SOILTYPE_AGR = dt$B_SOILTYPE_AGR,             B_HELP_WENR = dt$B_HELP_WENR,B_AER_CBS = dt$B_AER_CBS,             B_GWL_GLG = dt$B_GWL_GLG,B_GWL_GHG = dt$B_GWL_GHG,             B_GWL_ZCRIT = dt$B_GWL_ZCRIT,B_DRAIN = dt$B_DRAIN,             B_FERT_NORM_FR = dt$B_FERT_NORM_FR,B_SLOPE_DEGREE = dt$B_SLOPE_DEGREE,             B_GWP = dt$B_GWP,B_AREA_DROUGHT = dt$B_AREA_DROUGHT,             B_CT_PSW = dt$B_CT_PSW,B_CT_NSW = dt$B_CT_NSW,             B_SOMERS_BC = NA_real_,B_DRAIN_SP = NA_real_,B_DRAIN_WP = NA_real_,             A_SOM_LOI = dt$A_SOM_LOI,A_SOM_LOI_MLMAX = dt$a_som_loi_csat_top,             A_CLAY_MI = dt$A_CLAY_MI,A_SAND_MI = dt$A_SAND_MI,             A_SILT_MI = dt$A_SILT_MI,A_DENSITY_SA = NA_real_,             A_FE_OX = dt$A_FE_OX,A_AL_OX = dt$A_AL_OX,             A_PH_CC = dt$A_PH_CC,A_N_RT = dt$A_N_RT,A_CN_FR = dt$A_CN_FR,             A_S_RT = dt$A_S_RT,A_N_PMN = dt$A_N_PMN,A_P_AL = dt$A_P_AL,             A_P_CC = dt$A_P_CC,A_P_WA = dt$A_P_WA,A_P_SG = dt$A_P_SG,             A_CEC_CO = dt$A_CEC_CO,A_CA_CO_PO = dt$A_CA_CO_PO,             A_MG_CO_PO = dt$A_MG_CO_PO,A_K_CO_PO = dt$A_K_CO_PO,             A_K_CC = dt$A_K_CC,A_MG_CC = dt$A_MG_CC,A_MN_CC = dt$A_MN_CC,             A_ZN_CC = dt$A_ZN_CC,A_CU_CC = dt$A_CU_CC, D_SA_W = dt$D_SA_W,             D_RO_R = dt$D_RO_R, output ='scores')      # show output   cols1 <- colnames(o1)[grepl('esd_prod|bln_prod',colnames(o1))]   knitr::kable(o1[,mget(cols1)],caption='BLN soil quality scores for ESS crop production') # temporary fix: add three variables to bln_farm_hf   dt[,ID := id]   dt[,c("B_SOMERS_BC","B_DRAIN_SP","B_DRAIN_WP") := NA_real_]      # test the BLN field function via bln_field_dt and give only the final score   o2 <- bln_field_dt(dt,output = 'scores')      # show output   cols2 <- colnames(o2)[grepl('esd_prod|bln_prod',colnames(o2))]   knitr::kable(o2[,mget(cols2)],caption='BLN soil quality scores for ESS crop production')

title: bln_ess_groundwater
text: Groundwater used source drinking water, irrigation, supply natural habitats water. Groundwater must continuously recharged precipitation infiltrates soil. Soil plays pivotal role ensuring ample clean groundwater. Soils may buffer groundwater recharge, filter nutrients, breakdown (organic) contaminants pesticides. important monitor soil functions support groundwater ecosystem services. agricultural soils cover large areas, may subject operations hinder soil functions support groundwater use large machines may compact soil, use manure, fertilisers,pesticides. BLN evaluates following soil functions: groundwater recharge buffering nitrogen soil water buffering pesticides

title: bln_ess_groundwater
text: Groundwater recharge evaluated bln_wat_groundwater_recharge bln_bbwp_bw functions. evaluations also used separately OBIC BBWP packages (Verweij et al., 2023; Ros & Verweij, 2023). first function, bln_wat_groundwater_recharge, evaluates well water can infiltrate seep groundwater. affected soil’s cultivation (B_LU_BRP), risk soil compaction (B_SC_WENR), groundwater level (B_GWL_CLASS), presence drains, soil texture, use green manure. inputs, function calculates soil permeability risks sealing soil compaction, hamper groundwater recharge. second function, bln_bbwp_bw, evaluates well soil can hold onto water sufficient time infiltrate. also depends cultivation, groundwater level soil texture unaffected soil compaction risk. Instead, function considers whether soil located drought-prone area HELP code corresponding fields location (Van Bakel et al., 2005). HELP codes relate water needs types landuse. See examples BLN functions . illustrate indicators react changes soil texture, groundwater level, crop type.
code: water_recharge <- bln_wat_groundwater_recharge(       ID = 15,       B_LU_BRP = 259,       B_SC_WENR = 3,       B_GWL_CLASS = 'VI',       B_DRAIN = TRUE,       A_CLAY_MI = 20,       A_SAND_MI = 65,       A_SILT_MI = 10,       A_SOM_LOI = 5,       M_GREEN = FALSE       )  water_buffering <- bln_bbwp_bw(       ID = 15,       B_LU_BRP = 259,       B_HELP_WENR = 'Mn25C',       B_GWL_CLASS = 'VI',       B_AREA_DROUGHT = TRUE,       A_CLAY_MI = 20,       A_SAND_MI = 65,       A_SILT_MI = 10,       A_SOM_LOI = 5,       penalty = TRUE       )

title: BLN introduction
text: crucial role healthy soil achieving sustainable food production environment increasingly recognized, importance proper assessment soil quality. Healthy soils just growing medium crops, regulate support essential ecosystem services, water purification, carbon sequestration, nutrient cycling, provide habitats biodiversity. Improving sustaining soil health therefore key sustainable crop production. date, many attempts made develop indices assessing soil health, operational reproducible methodology assess soil health developed far. broad consensus multiple aspects soils (e.g., chemistry, structure, biology) interactions need considered. , various approaches proposed translate soil attributes indicators aggregate index, including (advanced) statistical methods refined expert knowledge systems. approaches however often highly dependent costly soil measures, difficult interpret, easily applicable across spatial scales, ranging field regions. overcome challenges, Ros et al. (2022) introduced new soil assessment framework, open soil index (OSI). OSI builds extensive soil agronomic research maintain direct link objective (sustainable crop production), leverages routine laboratory data public databases make large-scale application affordable, modular design allow easy adjustment expansion, developed open-source environment assure transparency, provides advice field-level farming practices. way, OSI strives provide operational soil assessment valorizes soil health therewith promote sustainable soil management. 2021 onwards, soil scientists, agronomy researchers, farm advisors extension service providers collaborated expand OSI approach include multiple ecosystem services. OSI strongly focuses interpretion soil health view crop production, many ecosystem services recognized crucial societal objectives soil can contribute.Relevant soil ecosystem services Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) include delivery healthy food (SDG2 SDG3) also clean sufficient water (SDG6), mitigation climate (SDG13), support biodiversity protection land degradation (SDG15). Engaging farmers consider SDGs requires extension framework include environmental soil functions. newly developed framework follows conceptual approach OSI expands soil health assessment view ecosystem services. full description given (Dutch) report Bodemindicatoren Landbouwgronden Nederland, implemented BLN R package. tutorial gives short explanation package focussing main functionalities R package.

what: calculate BLN for a single field
title: BLN introduction
text: Lets see assess soil quality single field. First select first field given crop rotation scheme 11 years. basically subset farm contains soil field properties last 11 years, 2012 2022. subsequently use function bln_field() calculate different soil indicators soil scores. Note possible inputs given whereas visual soil assessment observations (ending “_bsc”) management information required current BLN calculation. therefore default set NA. start request soil indicators. numerical input variables BLN. categorial input variables BLN. simplify, one can also use data.table input. case use function bln_field_dt(). function checks whether desired input variables present. default option calculate C saturation RothC switched . , illustration shows use bln_field_dt retrieve BLN indicators. interpretation 35 soil indicators, one can look vignette("bln_column_description") ask BLN scores, summarizing contribution soil various ecosystem services, one can ask scores output. Just replace argument output scores rather indicators. also possible ask : just set argument output equal , default option. summarize BLN score single field. Given hierarchical structure BLN soil quality assesment, following scores calculated: BLN total score represents overall integrated soil quality assessment, score varies zero (serious bottlenecks present) one (quality optimal crop rotation plan field) ESD crop production: quality score reflecting ability soil sustain crop production ESD climate mitigation: quality score reflecting ability soil store carbon soil mitigate climate change ESD nutrient cycling: quality score reflecting ability soil recycle (regional) nutrients efficiently ESD water: quality score reflecting ability soil retain purify water leaching ground surface water Besides four ecoystem services provided soil, two ESS can shown detail, thereby reflecting underlying processes controlling ESS. First, ESS crop production can separated soil quality assessment view chemical, physical biological soil functions contributing ability soils sustain crop production. Second, ESS water involves separate assessment capacity soils retain recharge groundwater, purify water leaching surface water one hand groundwater . BLN scores field 1

text: ID (character) field id B_LU_BRP (numeric) crop code B_SC_WENR (integer) risk subsoil compaction derived risk assessment study Van den Akker (2006). Options include: 1,2,3,4,5,10,11,401,901 902. B_AER_CBS (character) agricultural economic region Netherlands (CBS, 2016) B_GWL_CLASS (character) groundwater table class B_SLOPE_DEGREE (numeric) slope field (degrees) A_P_CC (numeric) plant available P content, measured via 0.01M CaCl2 extraction (mg / kg) A_P_SG (numeric) P-saturation index (%) A_AL_OX (numeric) iron content soil (mmol / kg) A_FE_OX (numeric) aluminium content soil (mmol / kg) D_RO_R (numeric) risk surface water runs parcel D_SA_W (numeric) wet perimeter index field, fraction field surrounded water B_RO_R (numeric) mean D_RO_R soil LSW region. Optional. B_RO_R_SD (numeric) variance D_RO_R LSW region (standard deviation). Optional. B_P_CC (numeric) mean P-CaCl2 content soil LSW region (mg P / kg). Optional. B_P_CC_SD (numeric) variance P-CaCl2 content  soil LSW region (standard deviation) (mg P / kg). Optional. B_P_SG (numeric) mean P saturation degree soil LSW region (mg N / kg). Optional. B_P_SG_SD (numeric) variance P saturation degree soil LSW region (standard deviation) (%). Optional. B_AL_OX (numeric) mean Al-oxide content soil LSW region (%). Optional. B_AL_OX_SD (numeric) variance Al-oxide content soil LSW region (standard deviation) (mmol+ / kg). Optional. B_FE_OX (numeric) mean Fe-oxide content soil LSW region (mmol+ / kg). Optional. B_FE_OX_SD (numeric) variance Fe-oxide content soil LSW region (standard deviation) (mmol+ / kg). Optional. B_CT_PSW (numeric) critical target required reduction P loss agriculture (kg P / ha) reach targets KRW B_CT_PSW_MAX (numeric) max critical target P reduction loss (kg P / ha) penalty (boolean) option apply penalty high risk BBWP field indicators. Default TRUE.

title: Simulate SOC evolution using Roth-C for the Netherlands — bln_rothc_sim
text: A_SOM_LOI (numeric) percentage organic matter soil (%). A_CLAY_MI (numeric) clay content soil (%). A_DEPTH (numeric) Depth soil sample taken (m). Default set 0.3. B_DEPTH (numeric) Depth cultivated soil layer (m), simulation depth. Default set 0.3. cf_yield (numeric) relative yield correction factor (fraction) yield higher regional average M_TILLAGE_SYSTEM (character) gives tillage system applied. Options include NT (-till), ST (shallow-till), CT (conventional-till) DT (deep-till). rothc_rotation (data.table) Table crop rotation details crop management actions taken. Includes also crop inputs carbon. See details desired format. rothc_amendment (data.table) table following column names: year, month, P_NAME, P_DOSE, P_HC, P_OM, p_p2o5, month optional. rothc_parms (list) list simulation parameters controlling dynamics RothC Model. Default NULL. information, see details.

title: Simulate SOC evolution using Roth-C for the Netherlands — bln_rothc_sim
text: function simulates fate SOC given impact soil properties, weather management. following inputs mandatory: rothc_rotation, A_SOM_LOI (%), A_CLAY_MI (%). data optional. weather inputs given, estimated long-term average weather conditions Netherlands. organic amendment table includes columns year, month, P_NAME, P_DOSE, P_HC, P_OM, p_p2o5, month optional. P_NAME fertilizer name, P_DOSE units (kg / ha), P_HC humification coefficient (fraction), P_OM organic matter content ( crop table includes columns: year, B_LU (crop id), B_LU_NAME (crop name), B_LU_EOM_CROP (effective organic matter content, kg/ha), B_LU_EOM_CROPRESIDUE (effective organic matter content crop residues, kg/ha), B_LU_HC (humification coeffient,-). crop table might include measures M_GREEN, M_GREEN_PROPERLY, M_CROPRESIDUE, M_IRRIGATION M_RENEWAL, upper case. * M_GREEN_TIMING (character) month catch crop sown, options: (august,september,october,november,never) * M_CROPRESIDUE (boolean) gives whether crop residues amended soil harvest. * M_IRRIGATION (boolean) gives whether crop irrigated. * M_RENEWAL (boolean) gives whether grassland renewed (applicable grassland) simulation C via RothC model can adapted following parameters: initialize, c_fractions, dec_rates, simyears unit. list called 'rothc_parms'.
